715126f-a.text:
341-349 East 116th Street, west of the N.W. corner of First Ave. Nos. 343-347 is the East Harlem Health Center, (Department of Health). These buildings were formerly occupied by the Red Cross.
July 16, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

707713f-a.text:
First Avenue, west side, north from 116th Street. The truck in the foreground contains pilgrims to the annual Feast of OGu Lady of Mt. Carmel. Additional pictures of this feast will be found under
the heading "Festivals".
July 16, 1935.
P. L. Sperr, Photographer.

731599f-a.title: Feast of Our Lady of Mount Carmel.

731599f-c.title: Feast of Our Lady of Mount Carmel.

731599f-b.title: Feast of Our Lady of Mount Carmel.

731604f-b.title: Feast of Our Lady of Mount Carmel.
731604f-b.text:
(1)
Feast of Our Lady of Mt. Carmel: Fortune-teller, with a parrot,
115th Street east of Pleasant Avenue.
The gas tank belongs to the Standard Gas Light Company, it is
later to be demolished.
July 16, 1925.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
Another fortune-teller and his parrot receive the respectful attention of three small children on East 116th Street, between
First and Second Avenues.
July 16, 1925.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
Two fortune-tellers in the crowd on a street near Jefferson
Park.
July 16, 1925.
P. L. Sperr.

731684f-b.title: Feast of Saint Anthony of Padua.
731684f-b.text:
(1)
Feast of St. Anthony of Padua, 1929, No. 1. The parade held Saturday before Labor Day, shown turning csst on 116th Street from First Avenue, at the N.W. corner. This section bears a religious society banner, flanked by the American and Italian
flaga.
The Bank of America, a branch of which is shown here, will in a little over two years be consolidated with the National
City Bank.
August 31, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
No. 2. The same; the advance guard of the parade, bearing the statue of St. Anthony, anc followed by the band, is p oceeding
west on 11oth Street from First Avenue.
August 31, 192V.
P. 1  L. Sperr.  A ( gE 249  2 Y r
(:W 1
NO REPRODUCTIONS.  . READ  1( S:
(3)
No. 3. 106th Street east from First Avenue, showing the tower which is to be paraded on 106th Street on Labor Day, as uaua1. This year it is surmounted by a figure of Mary of the Immaculate
Conception.
August 31, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
